That is a valid point. Sadly, many artists and writers who contributed to the Harlem Renaissance did not receive the recognition or financial compensation they deserved during their lifetimes. Racism and discrimination made it challenging for African American artists to find publishers, galleries, and other avenues to showcase their work. As a result, many talented and influential artists, writers, and intellectuals were unable to achieve the recognition they deserved.

However, despite these obstacles, the Harlem Renaissance managed to create an impressive body of work that challenged stereotypes, represented the black experience in the United States, and pushed the boundaries of art and literature. The cultural and artistic legacy of the Harlem Renaissance continues to inspire and shape American culture today.

It's also important to note that the work of many of these artists and writers has been rediscovered and celebrated in recent years, thanks to renewed interest and recognition. The efforts of historians and cultural critics have helped to bring the work of these important figures back into the public eye, ensuring that their contributions to American culture are not forgotten.
